moves.1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3: I want my light squared bishop on c4, and eventually on b3.  should i be moving my bishop now, or is Nc3 fine?  i don't want to delay development on protecting middle pieces, but i also don't want to provide black the opportunity to keep my light-squared bishop off of that diagonal.
moves.3... f5: not certain what this opening is, but I don't like how black is already attacking my pawn.
moves.4. Bc4: perhaps i should have dealt w/ the pawn threat first?
moves.4... Nf6 5. Qe2: i had d3, exf5, and O-O
moves.8. Bxd5:
i figured that i'll lose a piece if Qxd5, but it'll open up the e file for my post castle rook.
either way, it's not looking good.
moves.10. Qd3: not used to having blunders like this.  just want to get her to safety
moves.14. Qxh7+ Kf8 15. Qh8+ Ke7 16. Qxg7+ Kd8: e6 is weak, if i can out number the attack
moves.17... Be5 18. Rxe5: probably not the best move, but i see an opportunity to go up one more in material.  it will leave all my pieces away from the attack, but thought i'd try it.
moves.18... Nxe5 19. Nxe6+ Bxe6 20. Qh8+ Kd7 2: accomplished.  as suspected, i have no pieces in the attack.
moves.21... Re4 22. Kf1 Bc4+ 23. d3 Nxd3: if i move cxd3, it's mate with Bxd3..Kg1...Re1!
moves.24. Bd2 Nf4+ 25. Kg1 Ne2+ 26. Kh1 Rd4 27: pretty bad game on both sides..  i'd be interested in hearing thoughts on the initial opening up until the queen got taken.
